title: Rabobank asks CBRE to value Van Diemen's Land Company
text:
There's plenty of beef about Australia's largest dairy farm, Chinese businessman-owned Van Diemen's Land Company in Tasmania.

Nearly four years after businessman Xianfeng Lu sensationally outbid ASX-listed TasFoods, which had lined up $250 million in fresh equity via Wilsons and PAC Partners, there's skittishness among some of its key backers.

The first is renowned agribusiness lender Rabobank, which has claim over a big piece of the company's assets.

Rabobank is understood to have had valuers casting a close eye over the business in recent weeks, calling in property specialists CBRE to value the company.

While sources close to the process said it was "business as usual", others at Van Diemen's Land are not so sure. They reckon it is not often CBRE-types make their way to northwestern Tasmania to kick its tyres - and when they did, there was usually something up.

There's also reports of a potential mutiny with management raising concerns over serious animal welfare and safety issues, according to the ABC. The ABC reported Van Diemen's Land's senior managers had written to Lu to call for "basic daily operational repairs and maintenance".
